consul-data-source-agent-config.body:
data "consul_agent_config" "$1" {
    # Exported Attributes
    # "datacenter" - The datacenter the agent is running in
    # "node_id" - The ID of the node the agent is running on
    # "node_name" - The name of the node the agent is running on
    # "server" - Boolean if the agent is a server or not
    # "revision" - The first 9 characters of the VCS revision of the build of Consul that is running
    # "version" - The version of the build of Consul that is running
}
consul-data-source-agent-config.description:
-> **Note:** The `consul_agent_config` resource differs from [`consul_agent_self`](/docs/providers/consul/d/agent_self.html),
providing less information but utilizing stable APIs. `consul_agent_self` will be
deprecated in a future release. The `consul_agent_config` data source returns
[configuration data](https://www.consul.io/api/agent.html#read-configuration)
from the agent specified in the `provider`.

consul-data-source-agent-self.body:
data "consul_agent_self" "$1" {
    # Exported Attributes
    # "acl_disabled_ttl"
    # "check_deregister_interval_min"
    # "check_reap_interval"
    # "dns" - A map of DNS configuration attributes.  See below for details on the
    # "enable_coordinates"
    # "version" - The version of the Consul agent.
    # "version_prerelease"
    # "version_revision"
}
consul-data-source-agent-self.description:
~> **Warning:** The `consul_agent_self` resource has been deprecated and will be removed
from a future release of the provider. Read the [upgrade instructions](/docs/providers/consul/upgrading.html#deprecation-of-consul_agent_self) for more information. The `consul_agent_self` data source returns
[configuration and status data](https://www.consul.io/docs/agent/http/agent.html#agent_self)
from the agent specified in the `provider`.

consul-data-source-key-prefix.body:
data "consul_key_prefix" "$1" {
    # path - (Required) This is the subkey path in Consul (which will be appended to the given `path_prefix`) to construct the full key that will be used to read the value.
    path = ""

    # name - (Required) This is the name of the key. This value of the key is exposed as `var.<name>`. This is not the path of the subkey in Consul.
    name = ""

    # path_prefix - (Required) Specifies the common prefix shared by all keys that will be read by this data source instance. In most cases, this will end with a slash to read a "folder" of subkeys.
    path_prefix = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    datacenter = ""

    # token - (Optional) The ACL token to use. This overrides the token that the agent provides by default.
    token = ""

    # subkey - (Optional) Specifies a subkey in Consul to be read. Supported values documented below. Multiple blocks supported.
    subkey = ""

    # default - (Optional) This is the default value to set for `var.<name>` if the key does not exist in Consul. Defaults to an empty string.
    default = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "datacenter" - The datacenter the keys are being read from.
    # "default" - (Optional) This is the default value to set for "var.<name>" if the key does not exist in Consul. Defaults to an empty string.
    # "path_prefix" - the common prefix shared by all keys being read.
    # "default" - (Optional) This is the default value to set for "var.<name>" if the key does not exist in Consul. Defaults to an empty string.
    # "var.<name>" - For each name given, the corresponding attribute
    # "default" - (Optional) This is the default value to set for "var.<name>" if the key does not exist in Consul. Defaults to an empty string.
    # "subkeys" - A map of the subkeys and values is set if no "subkey"
    # "default" - (Optional) This is the default value to set for "var.<name>" if the key does not exist in Consul. Defaults to an empty string.
}
consul-data-source-key-prefix.description:
Allows Terraform to read values from a "namespace" of Consul keys that
share a common name prefix.

consul-data-source-keys.body:
data "consul_keys" "$1" {
    # path - (Required) This is the path in Consul that should be read or written to.
    path = ""

    # name - (Required) This is the name of the key. This value of the key is exposed as `var.<name>`. This is not the path of the key in Consul.
    name = ""

    # key - (Required) Specifies a key in Consul to be read. Supported values documented below. Multiple blocks supported.
    key = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    datacenter = ""

    # token - (Optional) The ACL token to use. This overrides the token that the agent provides by default.
    token = ""

    # default - (Optional) This is the default value to set for `var.<name>` if the key does not exist in Consul. Defaults to an empty string.
    default = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "datacenter" - The datacenter the keys are being read from.
    # "default" - (Optional) This is the default value to set for "var.<name>" if the key does not exist in Consul. Defaults to an empty string.
    # "var.<name>" - For each name given, the corresponding attribute
    # "default" - (Optional) This is the default value to set for "var.<name>" if the key does not exist in Consul. Defaults to an empty string.
}
consul-data-source-keys.description:
The `consul_keys` resource reads values from the Consul key/value store.
This is a powerful way dynamically set values in templates.

consul-data-source-nodes.body:
data "consul_nodes" "$1" {
    # datacenter - (Optional) The Consul datacenter to query.  Defaults to the same value found in `query_options` parameter specified below, or if that is empty, the `datacenter` value found in the Consul agent that this provider is configured to talk to.
    datacenter = ""

    # query_options - (Optional) See below.
    query_options = ""

    # allow_stale - (Optional) When `true`, the default, allow responses from Consul servers that are followers.
    allow_stale = ""

    # require_consistent - (Optional) When `true` force the client to perform a read on at least quorum servers and verify the result is the same.  Defaults to `false`.
    require_consistent = ""

    # token - (Optional) Specify the Consul ACL token to use when performing the request.  This defaults to the same API token configured by the `consul` provider but may be overriden if necessary.
    token = ""

    # wait_index - (Optional) Index number used to enable blocking quereis.
    wait_index = ""

    # wait_time - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    wait_time = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "datacenter" - The datacenter the keys are being read from to.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "node_ids" - A list of the Consul node IDs.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "node_names" - A list of the Consul node names.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "nodes" - A list of nodes and details about each Consul agent.  The list of
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "id" - The Node ID of the Consul agent.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
}
consul-data-source-nodes.description:
The `consul_nodes` data source returns a list of Consul nodes that have
been registered with the Consul cluster in a given datacenter.  By specifying a
different datacenter in the `query_options` it is possible to retrieve a list of
nodes from a different WAN-attached Consul datacenter.

consul-data-source-service.body:
data "consul_catalog_service" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The service name to select.
    name = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) The Consul datacenter to query.  Defaults to the same value found in `query_options` parameter specified below, or if that is empty, the `datacenter` value found in the Consul agent that this provider is configured to talk to.
    datacenter = ""

    # query_options - (Optional) See below.
    query_options = ""

    # tag - (Optional) A single tag that can be used to filter the list of nodes to return based on a single matching tag..
    tag = ""

    # allow_stale - (Optional) When `true`, the default, allow responses from Consul servers that are followers.
    allow_stale = ""

    # require_consistent - (Optional) When `true` force the client to perform a read on at least quorum servers and verify the result is the same.  Defaults to `false`.
    require_consistent = ""

    # token - (Optional) Specify the Consul ACL token to use when performing the request.  This defaults to the same API token configured by the `consul` provider but may be overriden if necessary.
    token = ""

    # wait_index - (Optional) Index number used to enable blocking quereis.
    wait_index = ""

    # wait_time - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    wait_time = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "datacenter" - The datacenter the keys are being read from to.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "name" - The name of the service
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "tag" - The name of the tag used to filter the list of nodes in "service".
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "service" - A list of nodes and details about each endpoint advertising a
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "node_id" - The Node ID of the Consul agent advertising the service.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "Address" in the Consul Catalog).
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
}
consul-data-source-service.description:
`consul_service` provides details about a specific Consul service in a
given datacenter.  The results include a list of nodes advertising the specified
service, the node's IP address, port number, node ID, etc.  By specifying a
different datacenter in the `query_options` it is possible to retrieve a list of
services from a different WAN-attached Consul datacenter. This data source is different from the `consul_services` (plural) data
source, which provides a summary of the current Consul services.

consul-data-source-services.body:
data "consul_services" "$1" {
    # datacenter - (Optional) The Consul datacenter to query.  Defaults to the same value found in `query_options` parameter specified below, or if that is empty, the `datacenter` value found in the Consul agent that this provider is configured to talk to.
    datacenter = ""

    # query_options - (Optional) See below.
    query_options = ""

    # allow_stale - (Optional) When `true`, the default, allow responses from Consul servers that are followers.
    allow_stale = ""

    # require_consistent - (Optional) When `true` force the client to perform a read on at least quorum servers and verify the result is the same.  Defaults to `false`.
    require_consistent = ""

    # token - (Optional) Specify the Consul ACL token to use when performing the request.  This defaults to the same API token configured by the `consul` provider but may be overriden if necessary.
    token = ""

    # wait_index - (Optional) Index number used to enable blocking quereis.
    wait_index = ""

    # wait_time - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    wait_time = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "datacenter" - The datacenter the keys are being read from to.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "names" - A list of the Consul services found.  This will always contain the
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "services.<service>" - For each name given, the corresponding attribute is a
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "tags" - A map of the tags found for each service.  If more than one service
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
}
consul-data-source-services.description:
The `consul_services` data source returns a list of Consul services that
have been registered with the Consul cluster in a given datacenter.  By
specifying a different datacenter in the `query_options` it is possible to
retrieve a list of services from a different WAN-attached Consul datacenter. This data source is different from the `consul_service` (singular) data
source, which provides a detailed response about a specific Consul service.

consul-resource-agent-service.body:
resource "consul_agent_service" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the service.
    name = ""

    # address - (Optional) The address of the service. Defaults to the address of the agent.
    address = ""

    # port - (Optional) The port of the service.
    port = ""

    # tags - (Optional) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "address" - The address of the service.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
    # "id" - The ID of the service, defaults to the value of "name".
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
    # "name" - The name of the service.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
    # "port" - The port of the service.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
    # "tags" - The tags of the service.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
}
consul-resource-agent-service.description:
!> The `consul_agent_service` resource has been deprecated in version 2.0.0 of the provider
and will be removed in a future release. Please read the [upgrade guide](/docs/providers/consul/upgrading.html#deprecation-of-consul_agent_service)
for more information. Provides access to the agent service data in Consul. This can be used to
define a service associated with a particular agent. Currently, defining
health checks for an agent service is not supported.

consul-resource-catalog-entry.body:
resource "consul_catalog_entry" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the service
    name = ""

    # node - (Required) The name of the node being added to, or referenced in the catalog.
    node = ""

    # address - (Required) The address of the node being added to, or referenced in the catalog.
    address = ""

    # service - (Optional) A service to optionally associated with the node. Supported values are documented below.
    service = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    datacenter = ""

    # token - (Optional) ACL token.
    token = ""

    # address - (Optional) The address of the service. Defaults to the
    address = ""

    # token - (Optional) ACL token.
    token = ""

    # id - (Optional) The ID of the service. Defaults to the `name`.
    id = ""

    # token - (Optional) ACL token.
    token = ""

    # token - (Optional) ACL token.
    token = ""

    # port - (Optional) The port of the service.
    port = ""

    # token - (Optional) ACL token.
    token = ""

    # tags - (Optional) A list of values that are opaque to Consul,
    tags = ""

    # token - (Optional) ACL token.
    token = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "address" - The address of the service.
    # "token" - (Optional) ACL token.
    # "node" - The ID of the service, defaults to the value of "name".
    # "token" - (Optional) ACL token.
}
consul-resource-catalog-entry.description:
!> The `consul_catalog_entry` resource has been deprecated in version 2.0.0 of the provider
and will be removed in a future release. Please read the [upgrade guide](/docs/providers/consul/upgrading.html#deprecation-of-consul_catalog_entry)
for more information. Registers a node or service with the [Consul Catalog](https://www.consul.io/docs/agent/http/catalog.html#catalog_register).
Currently, defining health checks is not supported.

consul-resource-intention.body:
resource "consul_intention" "$1" {
    # source_name - (Optional) (Required, string) The name of the source service for the intention. This service does not have to exist.
    source_name = ""

    # destination_name - (Optional) (Required, string) The name of the destination service for the intention. This service does not have to exist.
    destination_name = ""

    # action - (Optional) (Required, string) The intention action. Must be one of `allow` or `deny`.
    action = ""

    # meta - (Optional) (Optional, map) Key/value pairs that are opaque to Consul and are associated with the intention.
    meta = ""

    # description - (Optional) (Optional, string) Optional description that can be used by Consul tooling, but is not used internally.
    description = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    datacenter = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the intention.
    # "datacenter" - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    # "source_name" - The source for the intention.
    # "datacenter" - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    # "destination_name" - The destination for the intention.
    # "datacenter" - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    # "description" - A description of the intention.
    # "datacenter" - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    # "meta" - Key/value pairs associated with the intention.
    # "datacenter" - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
}
consul-resource-intention.description:
[Intentions](https://www.consul.io/docs/connect/intentions.html) are used to define
rules for which services may connect to one another when using [Consul Connect](https://www.consul.io/docs/connect/index.html). It is appropriate to either reference existing services or specify non-existent services
that will be created in the future when creating intentions. This resource can be used
in conjunction with the `consul_service` datasource when referencing services
registered on nodes that have a running Consul agent.

consul-resource-key-prefix.body:
resource "consul_key_prefix" "$1" {
    # subkeys - (Required) A mapping from subkey name (which will be appended to the given `path_prefix`) to the value that should be stored at that key. Use slashes, as shown in the above example, to create "sub-folders" under the given path prefix.
    subkeys = ""

    # path_prefix - (Required) Specifies the common prefix shared by all keys that will be managed by this resource instance. In most cases this will end with a slash, to manage a "folder" of keys.
    path_prefix = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    datacenter = ""

    # token - (Optional) The ACL token to use. This overrides the token that the agent provides by default.
    token = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "datacenter" - The datacenter the keys are being read/written to.
    # "subkeys" - (Required) A mapping from subkey name (which will be appended to the given "path_prefix") to the value that should be stored at that key. Use slashes, as shown in the above example, to create "sub-folders" under the given path prefix.
}
consul-resource-key-prefix.description:
Allows Terraform to manage a "namespace" of Consul keys that share a common
name prefix. Like `consul_keys`, this resource can write values into the Consul key/value
store, but *unlike* `consul_keys` this resource can detect and remove extra
keys that have been added some other way, thus ensuring that rogue data
added outside of Terraform will be removed on the next run. This resource is thus useful in the case where Terraform is exclusively
managing a set of related keys. To avoid accidentally clobbering matching data that existed in Consul before
a `consul_key_prefix` resource was created, creation of a key prefix instance
will fail if any matching keys are already present in the key/value store.
If any conflicting data is present, you must first delete it manually. ~> **Warning** After this resource is instantiated, Terraform takes control
over *all* keys with the given path prefix, and will remove any matching keys
that are not present in the configuration. It will also delete *all* keys under
the given prefix when a `consul_key_prefix` resource is destroyed, even if
those keys were created outside of Terraform.

consul-resource-keys.body:
resource "consul_keys" "$1" {
    # value - (Required) The value to write to the given path.
    value = ""

    # path - (Required) This is the path in Consul that should be written to.
    path = ""

    # key - (Required) Specifies a key in Consul to be written. Supported values documented below.
    key = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    datacenter = ""

    # token - (Optional) The ACL token to use. This overrides the token that the agent provides by default.
    token = ""

    # delete - (Optional) If true, then the key will be deleted when either its configuration block is removed from the configuration or the entire resource is destroyed. Otherwise, it will be left in Consul. Defaults to false.
    delete = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "datacenter" - The datacenter the keys are being written to.
    # "delete" - (Optional) If true, then the key will be deleted when either its configuration block is removed from the configuration or the entire resource is destroyed. Otherwise, it will be left in Consul. Defaults to false.
}
consul-resource-keys.description:
The `consul_keys` resource writes sets of individual values into Consul.
This is a powerful way to expose infrastructure details to clients. This resource manages individual keys, and thus it can create, update
and delete the keys explicitly given. However, it is not able to detect
and remove additional keys that have been added by non-Terraform means.
To manage *all* keys sharing a common prefix, and thus have Terraform
remove errant keys not present in the configuration, consider using the
`consul_key_prefix` resource instead.

consul-resource-node.body:
resource "consul_node" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the node being added to, or referenced in the catalog.
    name = ""

    # address - (Required) The address of the node being added to, or referenced in the catalog.
    address = ""

    # meta - (Optional) (Optional, map) Key/value pairs that are associated with the node.
    meta = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "address" - The address of the service.
    # "meta" - (Optional, map) Key/value pairs that are associated with the node.
    # "name" - The name of the service.
    # "meta" - (Optional, map) Key/value pairs that are associated with the node.
    # "meta" - (Optional, map) Key/value pairs that are associated with the node.
    # "meta" - (Optional, map) Key/value pairs that are associated with the node.
}
consul-resource-node.description:
Provides access to Node data in Consul. This can be used to define a
node. Currently, defining health checks is not supported.

consul-resource-prepared-query.body:
resource "consul_prepared_query" "$1" {
    # regexp - (Required) The regular expression to match with. When using `name_prefix_match`, this regex is applied against the query name.
    regexp = ""

    # regexp - (Required) The regular expression to match with. When using `name_prefix_match`, this regex is applied against the query name.
    regexp = ""

    # type - (Required) The type of template matching to perform. Currently only `name_prefix_match` is supported.
    type = ""

    # service - (Required) The name of the service to query.
    service = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the prepared query. Used to identify the prepared query during requests. Can be specified as an empty string to configure the query as a catch-all.
    name = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    datacenter = ""

    # token - (Optional) The ACL token to use when saving the prepared query. This overrides the token that the agent provides by default.
    token = ""

    # stored_token - (Optional) The ACL token to store with the prepared query. This token will be used by default whenever the query is executed.
    stored_token = ""

    # session - (Optional) The name of the Consul session to tie this query's lifetime to.  This is an advanced parameter that should not be used without a complete understanding of Consul sessions and the implications of their use (it is recommended to leave this blank in nearly all cases).  If this parameter is omitted the query will not expire.
    session = ""

    # tags - (Optional) The list of required and/or disallowed tags.  If a tag is in this list it must be present.  If the tag is preceded with a "!" then it is disallowed.
    tags = ""

    # only_passing - (Optional) When `true`, the prepared query will only return nodes with passing health checks in the result.
    only_passing = ""

    # near - (Optional) Allows specifying the name of a node to sort results near using Consul's distance sorting and network coordinates. The magic `_agent` value can be used to always sort nearest the node servicing the request.
    near = ""

    # nearest_n - (Optional) Return results from this many datacenters, sorted in ascending order of estimated RTT.
    nearest_n = ""

    # datacenters - (Optional) Remote datacenters to return results from.
    datacenters = ""

    # datacenters - (Optional) Remote datacenters to return results from.
    datacenters = ""

    # dns - (Optional) Settings for controlling the DNS response details. `ttl` - (Optional) The TTL to send when returning DNS results.
    dns = ""

    # dns - (Optional) Settings for controlling the DNS response details. `ttl` - (Optional) The TTL to send when returning DNS results.
    dns = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the prepared query, generated by Consul.
    # "regexp" - (Required) The regular expression to match with. When using "name_prefix_match", this regex is applied against the query name.
}
consul-resource-prepared-query.description:
Allows Terraform to manage a Consul prepared query. Managing prepared queries is done using Consul's REST API. This resource is
useful to provide a consistent and declarative way of managing prepared
queries in your Consul cluster using Terraform.

consul-resource-service.body:
resource "consul_service" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (Required, string) The name of the service.
    name = ""

    # node - (Optional) (Required, string) The name of the node the to register the service on.
    node = ""

    # address - (Optional) (Optional, string) The address of the service. Defaults to the address of the node.
    address = ""

    # service_id - (Optional) If the service ID is not provided, it will be defaulted to the value of the `name` attribute.
    service_id = ""

    # port - (Optional) (Optional, int) The port of the service.
    port = ""

    # tags - (Optional) (Optional, set of strings) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
    tags = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    datacenter = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "service_id" - The ID of the service.
    # "datacenter" - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    # "address" - The address of the service.
    # "datacenter" - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    # "node" - The node the service is registered on.
    # "datacenter" - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    # "name" - The name of the service.
    # "datacenter" - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    # "port" - The port of the service.
    # "datacenter" - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    # "tags" - The tags of the service.
    # "datacenter" - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
}
consul-resource-service.description:
A high-level resource for creating a Service in Consul in the Consul catalog. This
is appropriate for registering [external services](https://www.consul.io/docs/guides/external.html) and
can be used to create services addressable by Consul that cannot be registered
with a [local agent](https://www.consul.io/docs/agent/basics.html). If the Consul agent is running on the node where this service is registered, it is
not recommended to use this resource.
